title-group.article-title: In Vitro Structure–Activity Relationship Stability Study of Antisense Oligonucleotide Therapeutics Using Biological Matrices and Nucleases

aff.named-content: DMPK, Research and Early Development Cardiovascular, Renal and Metabolism, BioPharmaceuticals R&D
Cell, Gene and RNA Therapeutics, Discovery Sciences, BioPharmaceuticals R&D

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 AstraZeneca R&D. Pharmacology Research & Perspectives published by British Pharmacological Society and American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics and John Wiley & Sons Ltd.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited and is not used for commercial purposes.

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: The primary degradation pathway for antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) involves endonuclease and exonuclease‐mediated breakdown. The effect of various chemical modifications on the stability of oligonucleotides has not been systematically investigated. The aim of this study was to develop in vitro assays to predict in vivo metabolism of ASOs. Stability studies of ASOs with varying phosphorothioate/phosphodiester (PS/PO) content were conducted using nucleolytic matrices (snake venom 3′‐exonuclease phosphodiesterase I [PDEI], mouse serum, and mouse liver homogenate) and analyzed by gel electrophoresis and liquid chromatography with ultraviolet and mass spectrometry detection (LC‐UV/MS). Both sequence composition and backbone chemistry play important roles in influencing the stability of ASOs. Nucleolytic sensitivity observed with PDEI and mouse serum shows that ASOs with one PO modification in the backbone have higher stability than ASOs having two or three PO links, and with a lower PO content, the sequence has a larger influence on stability. Furthermore, the impact of a 5‐methylcytidine nucleoside (MeC) on stability was observed. When the PO link was located after MeC (from 3′ end), resistance toward nuclease hydrolysis increased, while the PO modification being before MeC had no protective effect. Employing nucleases and comparing stability data with matrices of animal origin holds promise for a future fast‐track assessment of drug stability, enabling the efficient selection of optimal drug candidates for subsequent in vivo studies.

fn.p: Funding: The authors received no specific funding for this work.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: ASO molecules are single‐stranded nucleic acids consisting of approximately 15–30 nucleotides. They regulate gene expression through various mechanisms. Since the 1960s and 1970s, extensive research has been conducted to establish practical applications of ASOs [1, 2, 3]. Today, ASOs have emerged as a new class of therapeutic modalities with 10 drugs approved by the US Food and Drug Administration [4]. There are two major categories of ASOs, steric block and RNase H1 competent. The latter category comprises DNA/RNA mimic hybrid ASOs, which possess the unique ability to hybridize with RNA molecules. Through their interaction with the RNase H1 enzyme, they facilitate degradation of RNA, leading to a selective inhibition of gene expression at the sequence level [5, 6].

Susceptibility to degradation by extra‐ and intracellular nucleases is a major challenge for delivering unmodified phosphodiester ASO therapeutics and achieving target engagement. It is well‐known that unmodified oligonucleotides can degrade rapidly in biological matrices such as serum or living cells, with half‐lives of 5–30 min [7, 8, 9, 10]. Chemical modifications including nucleic acid backbone (1.0 generation), ribose sugar (2.0 generation), or nucleobase alternations (3.0 generation) [11] have been crucial in enhancing oligonucleotide stability. Introducing a sulfur atom in place of the non‐bridging oxygen atom in the phosphate backbone has led to ASOs with a phosphothioate (PS) backbone [12], resulting in improved stability against nucleases, increased binding affinity to proteins, improved pharmacokinetic (PK) properties, and enhanced cellular uptake [13]. However, using a PS backbone in ASOs often led to reduced target affinity [14], which is addressed by further chemically modifying ribose sugars with bridged nucleic acids (BNAs) such as locked nucleic acids (LNA) [15] or 2′,4′‐constrained 2′‐O‐ethyl bridged nucleic acids [16]. Additionally, the development of “gapmer” ASOs, combining the advantages of a PS backbone and BNAs, has been crucial in promoting stability and maintaining target affinity [15].

PS‐modified ASOs have been associated with adverse effects such as inflammation, hepatotoxicity, and thrombocytopenia [17, 18]. The introduction of LNAs in the flanking regions of gapmer ASOs led to a reduction in immunostimulatory response, higher potency, and improved binding affinities; however, it has also been linked to hepatic injury [19]. To mitigate these toxicities, introducing some PO linkages at the wings of a PS‐ASO has shown promise in reducing toxicity, possibly by altering ASO interactions with certain immune‐modulatory proteins [18]. Furthermore, to reduce retention of PS‐ASOs within organs and to modulate the duration of gene silencing, a PS/PO mixed backbone can be used to adapt stability toward nucleases [20].

Metabolism of ASOs differs from the typical metabolic pathways of small molecules by not engaging cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzymes. Instead, their primary metabolic pathway involves degradation by nucleases, employing both endo‐ and exonucleases. Studies have revealed that ASOs degrade in vivo through initial endonuclease cleavage followed by exonuclease‐driven hydrolysis [4]. However, in vitro studies have reported that ASO metabolism is driven by the activity of 3′‐exonucleases rather than 5′‐exonucleases and endonucleases [21].

In this study, a gapmer design of ASOs with varied PO and PS compositions, along with two different oligonucleotide sequences, was systematically investigated. The primary goal was to develop in vitro assays to predict ASO metabolism and systematically elucidate the contribution of the PS backbone to enhanced ASO stability. Our approach involved the application of gel electrophoresis and LC‐UV/MS techniques to study the nucleolytic degradation of selected ASOs in the presence of nucleases or biological matrices, such as mouse serum and mouse liver homogenate. Additionally, metabolite identification (MetID) of selected ASO compounds using high‐resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) enabled a comparative analysis of metabolite profiles across different biological matrices. This comprehensive study sheds light on crucial insights into ASO metabolism and stability, paving the way for advancements in the development of more effective and safer ASO therapeutics.

sec.title: Chemicals and Reagents
sec.p: Nuclease‐free water (Molecular Biology Reagent), magnesium chloride hexahydrate (for analysis EMSURE ACS, ISO, Reag. Ph Eur), ammonium acetate (NH4OAc, ACS reagent, ≥ 97%), ammonium bicarbonate (Reagent Plus, ≥ 99%), tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (pro analysis, ACS, Reag. Ph Eur), guanidine hydrochloride (for molecular biology, ≥ 99%), guanidine hydrochloride solution 6 M, Tris(2‐carboxyethyl)phosphine hydrochloride (TCEP‐HCl, bio‐ultra, ≥ 98%), l‐cysteine (≥ 98%), ammonium hydroxide solution (ACS reagent, 28.0%–30.0% NH3 basis), Tergitol, triethylamine (TEA, ≥ 99.5%), and tetrahydrofuran (THF, anhydrous, contained 250 ppm BHT, > 99.9%) were purchased from Merck Life Science (Solna, Sweden). Sodium acetate anhydrous (NaOAc, puris p.a., ≥ 99%), acetonitrile (ACN, Optima LC/MS grade), methanol (Optima LC/MS grade), sodium chloride (≥ 95.5%), TBE buffer (tris‐borate‐EDTA, 10X, Thermo Scientific), Hi‐density TBE sample buffer (5X), and TBE gels, 10% (both Invitrogen Novex), Tissue & Cell Lysis Solution (LGC Biosearch Technologies, Hoddeson, UK, cat. no. MTC096H) were obtained from Thermo Fisher (Stockholm, Sweden). 1,1,1,3,3,3‐hexafluoro‐2‐propanol (HFIP, > 99%) from TCI was ordered from Chemtronica (Sollentuna, Sweden). Proteinase K (20 mg/mL, cat. no. 19133) was obtained from Qiagen (Kista, Sweden) while ethidium bromide (10 mg/mL) was purchased from VWR (Stockholm, Sweden). Ultrapure water from Millipore Sigma (Merck KGaA, Burlington, MA, USA) was used for the preparation of all aqueous solutions. Clarity OTX 25 mg/well SPE plates were purchased from Phenomenex (Værløse, Denmark) while Evolute Oligo 1, 30 mg SPE plates were obtained from Biotage (manufacturing batch number: 654‐2‐03, Uppsala, Sweden). Pooled mouse serum (C57BL/6 strain) was purchased from Merck Life Science (catalogue number: M5905, source number: SLCQ4598, Solna, Sweden) and Envigo (code: S.R.‐0135, batch: 22‐1094, Indianapolis, IN, USA).

sec.title: Oligonucleotides Used in the Study
sec.p: Four oligonucleotides were selected for initial stability studies against PDEI, as shown in Table 1. A phosphodiester 12‐mer with a full PO backbone (Compound 1) was used as a positive control, a 16‐mer phosphorothioate LNA‐DNA‐LNA gapmer against MALAT1 (Compound 2) as a negative control, a 16‐mer phosphodiester LNA‐DNA‐LNA gapmer against MALAT1 (Compound 4) to test the effect of LNAs on the nucleolytic activity of nucleases, and a 16‐mer LNA‐DNA‐LNA gapmer with a mixed PS/PO backbone (PS‐PO‐PS = 9–3–3 from 5′ end, compound 5) as the target ASO. Compound 3 was an internal standard, while Compound 6 was target ASOs with sequences 1 and 2 and a PS/PO backbone. Details of the synthesis, purification, and analysis of these compounds are described in the Methods S1. In the second part of the study, a total of 83 ASOs with two different sequences (Figure 1) and three different mixed PS/PO backbone patterns were synthesized and tested.

caption.p: Summary of oligonucleotides chosen for the studies.

fn.p: Note: PO links are labeled as “o,” when not specified are PS modifications; lightface type, DNA; underline type, locked nucleic acid (LNA); MeC, 5‐methylcytidine.
Descriptions of a mixed PS/PO backbone and PO walk are shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Three backbone patterns of gapmer compounds with sequential replacement of PS backbone by one to three PO internucleotide linkages from 3′ to 5′ terminal (1 PO, 2 PO and 3 PO walk). Definitions: PS linker (red), PO linker (green in black box), DNA (light gray), LNA (blue). Numerical labelling of ASOs indicates the number of PS (red) and PO (green) modifications.

sec.title: Preparation of Mouse Liver Homogenate
sec.p: Mouse livers were perfused to remove blood and snap frozen until use. Frozen tissue was thawed on ice, cut with surgical scissors into small pieces, and placed in a round‐bottom tube. Cold homogenization buffer (100 mM TRIS–HCl, 1 mM MgCl2, pH 7.5 adjusted with 10 M HCl) was added at a ratio of 1 g tissue/3 mL buffer (4 folds dilution). Tissue homogenization was performed on ice using a Polytron PT 1200 homogenizer (Kinematica AG, Luzern, Switzerland) for several cycles (cycle: 4 s on/4 s off) to achieve a well‐homogenized material. The homogenate was collected in a 50‐mL Falcon tube on ice and centrifuged at 1000×g at +4°C for 20 min (Rotina 38R, Hettich Labinstrument AB, Sigtuna, Sweden). The supernatant was collected in a Falcon tube, mixed, and aliquoted into 2‐mL Eppendorf tubes. The tubes were snap frozen in a mixture of 99.5% ethanol and dry ice and subsequently stored at −80°C. Prior to use, the homogenate was diluted with a cold homogenization buffer to obtain a final sixfold final dilution.

sec.title: Sample Preparation for Nuclease Saturation Experiment
sec.p: DNA LoBind tubes were used to prepare solutions and samples for incubation. Standard solutions of ASOs were made in nuclease‐free water with a concentration range of 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 μM. Mouse serum (Envigo, Indianapolis, IN, USA) was prepared by a 1:1 dilution with nuclease‐free water. 50% mouse serum (68 μL) was spiked with 2 μL stock solution of ASOs, yielding incubation concentrations of 2.9, 5.7, 8.6, 11.4, and 14.3 μM, respectively. The resultant mixtures were incubated in a water bath for 3 and 6 h at 37°C. Following incubation, samples were quickly frozen in dry ice and stored at −20°C. The nucleolytic reaction was stopped enzymatically with a quench solution (Tissue & Cell Lysis Solution and Proteinase K) prepared according to the protocol published earlier [22]. Seventy microliters of stop solution were added to the frozen samples, and the quenched mixture was incubated at 60°C for 1 h in a water bath, then centrifuged at 2330×g at +4°C for 15 min (Rotanta 460R, Hettich Labinstrument AB, Sigtuna, Sweden). Eighty microliters of supernatant were analyzed by HPLC‐UV (Methods S1).

sec.title: Incubation With PDEI
sec.p: In vitro stability of synthesized oligonucleotides was studied in PDEI from Crotalus adamanteus (batches: SLCN1579, SLCP1594, vial of ≥ 100 units, 95% purity, Merck Life Science, Solna, Sweden). The PDEI enzyme was dissolved in 1 mL nuclease‐free water and aliquots (100 U/mL) were stored at −20°C until use. The oligonucleotide working solutions were prepared in NaOAc buffer (50 mM NaOAc, 10 mM MgCl2, pH = 7.4). All sample incubations were conducted in 96‐well plates. For 20‐h incubation, unused sample wells were filled with MilliQ water to maintain the surrounding humidity and temperature of the test sample wells, and the plates were prewarmed at 37°C for 2 h. The reaction was initiated by adding oligonucleotide working solutions to aliquoted PDEI. The final incubation mixture contained 5 μM ASO compound and 86 mU PDEI in 120 μL incubation media. Prior to incubation, plates were centrifuged for a few seconds at 150×g at +4°C. Plates prepared for 0‐h incubation were immediately stored at −80°C, while plates to be incubated for 20 h were sealed with PTFE/Silicone Cap Mat (Waters Sverige AB, Solna, Sweden) and incubated at 37°C in an in‐house‐made shaking incubator. After incubation, sample plates were sealed with Corning 96‐well Microplate Aluminum Sealing Tapes (Thermo Fisher, Stockholm, Sweden) and immediately stored at −80°C until sample preparation using solid‐phase extraction (SPE) and UPLC–MS analysis.

sec.title: Incubation With Mouse Serum and Mouse Liver Homogenate
sec.p: The oligonucleotide stock solutions were prepared in nuclease‐free water. Mouse serum (Merck Life Science, Solna, Sweden) or mouse liver homogenate, both 119 μL in volume, were added to previously aliquoted ASOs (0.6 nmol, 1 μL of 600 μM stock solution) in DNA LoBind 96‐well plates. The final concentration of analytes was 5 μM in 120 μL. The sample preparation procedure was the same as for incubation with PDEI (vide supra). Plates for 20‐h incubation were covered with Breathe‐Easy sealing membrane (Merck Life Science, Solna, Sweden) prior to placement in the in‐house‐made shaking incubator. All samples were stored at −80°C until subjected to SPE sample preparation and UPLC–MS analysis.

sec.title: SPE Protocol
sec.p: Frozen previously incubated samples were thawed at room temperature, centrifuged for 1 min at 240×g at +4°C, and kept on ice. An aliquot of 80 μL sample was added into 90 μL of quench solution premixed with 10 μL of 4 μM internal standard (MALAT1‐Full P34S) previously aliquoted to each well in a DNA LoBind 96‐well plate. The final concentration of the internal standard after SPE and reconstitution in 80 μL nuclease‐free water was 0.5 μM. The quench solution (6 M guanidine hydrochloride, 1% Tergitol, 10 mM TCEP, 8 mM l‐cysteine) was always prepared fresh on the day of use and stored at +4°C. The plate was shaken on an Eppendorf MixMate (VWR, Stockholm, Sweden) at 800 rpm for 15 min and then centrifuged at 245×g for 1 min. Afterwards, the plate was transferred to an automated sample preparation workstation (Extrahera LV‐200, Biotage, Uppsala, Sweden) for SPE sample extraction. The SPE buffers were prepared as follows: equilibration buffer: 50 mM NH4OAc (pH = 5.5); wash buffer (1): 50 mM NH4OAc (pH = 5.5) was mixed with ACN (50:50 [v:v] = water:ACN, final concentration of NH4OAc was 25 mM); wash buffer (2): 3 M guanidine hydrochloride, 1% Tergitol; elution buffer: 200 mM NH4HCO3 (pH = 9.5) was mixed with ACN and THF (50:40:10 [v:v:v] = water:ACN:THF, final concentration of NH4HCO3 was 100 mM). The pH was adjusted using a high concentration of acetic acid for the preparation of 50 mM NH4OAc and ammonium hydroxide for the preparation of 200 mM NH4HCO3.

sec.title: PDEI and Mouse Serum SPE Protocol
sec.p: Biotage Evolute Oligo 1, 30 mg plates was used to run SPE on samples incubated with PDEI and mouse serum. SPE plates were conditioned once with 500 μL methanol followed by equilibration with 750 μL equilibration buffer one time, after which the plate was left to dry for 5 s. The samples in the DNA LoBind 96‐well plate were pretreated by adding 180 μL equilibration buffer to each well and 335 μL of the mixture was loaded onto the conditioned and equilibrated SPE plate followed by five times premixing (applied pressure: 0.1 bar, 160 s; 0.2 bar, 160 s; 1 bar, 60 s). The SPE plate was washed three times with 500 μL wash buffer (1) (applied pressure: 0.8 bar, 45 s; 1 bar, 45 s). The plate was left to dry for 30 s prior to the elution step. The samples were eluted two times by adding 250 μL elution buffer (applied pressure: 0 bar, 120 s; 0.4 bar, 120 s) and collected in the DNA LoBind 96‐well plate.

sec.title: Mouse Liver Homogenate SPE Protocol
sec.p: SPE was done on Clarity OTX 25 mg/well plates. The protocol was the same as previously described (vide supra) with the following modifications: SPE washing phase was done in two steps. First, samples were washed once with 500 μL wash buffer (2), and afterwards three times with 500 μL wash buffer (1). During both steps, the applied pressure was 0.8 bar, 45 s; 1 bar, 45 s; 2 bar, 45 s. The plate was left to dry for 30 s prior to the elution step. The samples were eluted two times with 250 μL elution buffer (applied pressure: 0 bar, 120 s; 0.4 bar, 120 s; 2.5 bar, 120 s) and collected in a DNA LoBind 96‐well plate.

After SPE, all extracted sample plates were dried overnight under nitrogen flow at room temperature (Techne 96‐Well Sample Concentrator [Minneapolis, MN, USA]). Sealed plates were stored at −20°C or directly reconstituted forUPLC‐MS analysis.

sec.title: UPLC‐QToF MS Analysis
sec.p: Prior to LC‐MS analysis, all SPE samples were reconstituted in 80 μL nuclease‐free water, followed by shaking at 800 rpm for 20 min (Eppendorf MixMate, VWR, Stockholm, Sweden) and centrifuged at 2700×g for 10 min at +4°C. LC‐MS analysis was carried out using a 1290 Infinity UPLC system (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) comprised of a binary pump, a thermostatically controlled column compartment, and an autosampler coupled to a HP Agilent 1100 HPLC G1315A Diode Array Detector (DAD) and 6560 Ion Mobility LC/QToF mass analyzer (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Chromatographic separation was achieved using a UPLC Acquity Premier Oligonucleotide BEH C18 column (130 Å, 1.7 μm, 2.1 mm × 100 mm; Waters [Solna, Sweden]) heated at 60°C. Mobile phase (A) was an aqueous solution of 200 mM HFIP and 7.5 mM TEA; mobile phase (B) was 100% methanol. There was no pH adjustment done on mobile phase (A). Injection volume was 5 μL, and the flow rate was 0.3 mL/min. Chromatographic separation was done under the following gradient (min–%B): 0–5; 1–5; 4–15; 10–30; 10.5–80; 12.5–80; 13–5. The total run time was 14 min.

UV detection was performed using DAD (260 nm, spectral bandwidth 4 nm), and the mass spectrometer was configured with a Dual Agilent Jet Stream Electrospray Ionization (Dual AJS ESI) source. The ion source operated with the following parameters: gas temperature (300°C), drying gas (8 L/min), nebulizer gas pressure (35 psi), sheath gas temperature (350°C), sheath gas flow (11 L/min), capillary voltage (3.5 kV), and nozzle voltage (1 kV). The mass spectrometer operated in negative ion mode (m/z scan range: 600–3000) with 28,000 mass resolving power at m/z 1900. Instrument control and data acquisition were done using MassHunter Workstation LC/MS Data Acquisition software (version B.09.00, build 9.0.9044.1 SP1, Agilent technologies Inc. 2018). Data analysis was performed using MassHunter Workstation Qualitative Analysis software (version 10.0, build 10.0.10305.0, Agilent technologies Inc. 2006–2018). The envelope peaks of −3 charged ions of interest were integrated as single m/z expansion for chromatogram (symmetric, ±1 m/z). For data processing, selected samples were also analyzed by UPLC‐orbitrap MS (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Details of UPLC separation and orbitrap MS conditions are shown in Methods S1.

sec.title: Data Analysis for Metabolite Profiling and Identification
sec.p: Representative incubated in vitro samples analyzed by UPLC‐QToF MS or Orbitrap MS were processed for metabolite identification and profiling using Mass‐MetaSite V4.6, Macro Molecules mode, in Oniro WebMetaBase platform (Mass Analytica, Spain) or BioPharma Finder V5.1 oligonucleotide analysis module (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Expected degradation reactions such as hydrolysis of the internucleotide bond and deamination were considered.

sec.title: Stability Assessments of Oligonucleotides Toward PDEI and Mouse Serum
sec.p: Initial stability investigations were performed with snake venom PDEI, a 3′ → 5′ exonuclease [23, 24, 25, 26], to establish conditions that fully degraded an unmodified PO‐ASO (“12‐mer”) (Figure S1). Then, stability assessment of the ASOs was performed with 86 mU of PDEI for 0, 1, 3, and 20 h, and analyzed by gel electrophoresis (Methods S1).

As shown in Figure 2, the assay conditions allow for a clear differentiation between the stable MALAT1‐Full PS gapmer and the hydrolysable MALAT1‐Full PO with LNA in the wings (Table 1, no. 4). We further tested a mixed PS/PO backbone ASO (“sequence1 [9–3–3]”; Compound 5, Table 1). Interestingly, this ASO showed a degradation time profile comparable to the full‐PO (Figure 2, lane 4 vs. lane 3). The LNA modification at the wings increased stability for 1 to 3 h (12‐mer vs. MALAT1‐Full PO and Sequence 1 [9–3–3]).

caption.p: Nuclease assay for stability assessment of selected compounds (Table 1) incubated with phosphodiesterase I (3′ → 5′) for 0, 1, 3, and 20 h. Positive control: 12‐mer; negative control: MALAT1‐Full PS; the effect of LNAs on stability: MALAT1‐Full PO; mixed PO/PS backbone: Compound with sequence 1 and 3 PO walk from 5′→ 3′ end in order 9 PS 3 PO 3 PS: Sequence 1 (9–3‐3). (A) a summary of gel images, (B) band analysis showing remaining percentage of selected compounds after incubation with PDEI. Data represent mean and SEM from n = 2 replicates, 4 data points.

sec.p: Based on these findings, we explored the impact of varying PO content and positions in the backbone of an ASO gapmer. A total of 83 ASOs with two different sequences (Figure 1), and three different mixed PS/PO backbone patterns were synthesized and tested. All ASOs (both sequences and all three PO walks) were incubated under the same conditions: 0.6 nmol ASO with 86 mU of PDEI for 20 h at 37°C. Samples were prepared with solid‐phase extraction (SPE, details in Figure S2), achieving a mean extraction recovery of 68% ± 6% for all three reference ASOs (Methods S1 and Table S1). Following SPE, the samples were analyzed using UPLC–high‐resolution MS. A set of typical stability assessment chromatograms of one ASO is shown in Figure S3.

A comprehensive overview of the metabolic stability of all ASOs incubated with PDEI is presented in Figure 3 and Figure S4, revealing several noteworthy observations. It was observed that all ASOs with PO linkage(s) at the very 3′ end (14–1; 13–2; 12–3, labeled as 0 in Figure 3) are completely metabolized over a 20‐h incubation period. This indicates that LNAs do not offer protection against PDEI when one or more PO modifications are located closest to the 3′ end. Conversely, if one or two PS modifications are positioned at the 3′ end of an ASO backbone, LNA chemistry provides protection.

caption.p: Comparison of stability for 5 μM ASOs with varied PO and PS composition and explored for two different oligonucleotide sequences incubated for 20 h with 86 mU PDEI (light gray) or 100% mouse serum (dark gray). Top panel: 1 PO walk; middle panel: 2 PO walk; bottom panel: 3 PO walk. (A) sequence 1, (B) sequence 2. Data represent mean and SEM from n = 3 replicates.

sec.p: ASO stability was further tested in mouse serum, known for its high 3′‐exonuclease content [27]. Both series of analytes (sequence 1 and 2 with three different PO walks, respectively) were incubated in 100% serum, mirroring the approach with PDEI (Figure 3 and Figure S5). The general trend of higher PS content in an ASO leading to higher stability was confirmed in line with previous observations [20, 28]. However, our findings also indicate that nucleolytic stability is contingent upon the sequence, with sequence 1 exhibiting greater stability compared to sequence 2 (Figure 3). Similar to the findings with PDEI, LNAs did not provide protection to ASOs with 1, 2, or 3 PO linkages at the 3′ end as they appeared to be completely metabolized after 20 h of incubation. Conversely, ASOs with one or two PS modifications at the 3′ end (in the LNA wing) showed higher stability, and this stability did not seem to be sequence‐dependent as observed with PDEI.

We compared nucleolytic stability of ASOs exposed to PDEI and mouse serum to assess whether the nucleolytic potential of 86 mU PDEI matches 100% mouse serum. Figure 3A shows the comparison in stability between two nucleolytic matrices, PDEI and mouse serum, for sequence 1. Figure 3B displays stability results of sequence 2. It is observed in Figure 3B that metabolic degradation is very similar between PDEI and mouse serum, especially for ASOs with 1 PO modification in the backbone (top graph). The stability of ASOs with the 2 PO and 3 PO walk in the 3′ LNA wing for sequence 2 (Figure 3B, middle and bottom graphs), appears higher in PDEI than in mouse serum. This is contrasting to the observations for sequence 1 (Figure 3A, middle and bottom graphs), which is observed to be more stable in mouse serum (discussed later).

As expected, when comparing the stability of ASOs with different PO content, we observed that higher PO content in a backbone decreases stability toward both nucleolytic matrices in both sequences (Figure 3). Additionally, we found that having nine consecutive PS modifications at the 3′ end does not block exonuclease activity. However, we noticed increased stability in some compounds with PO linkages before Position 9. Specifically, ASOs with a PS to PO swap after 5‐methylcytidine (MeC) from the 3′ end showed increased stability (sequence 1 [9–1–5] and sequence 2 [10–1–4 and 8–1–6]), while a PS to PO swap before MeC from the 3′ terminal resulted in decreased stability (Figure 3 top panel and Figure 4). Furthermore, enhanced stability was observed when the PS to PO swap was located between thymidine and adenosine nucleosides in the direction 5′ T–A 3′ (sequence 1 [6–1‐8] and sequence 2 [7–1–7]), but not between 5′ A–T 3′ or 5′ T–T 3′ (Figure 3 top panel and Figure 4). We observed a similar trend for sequence 2 ASOs with 2 PO and 3 PO walks, particularly noting increased stability for specific patterns; it is evident that sequence‐dependent stability is more readily observed for the ASOs with 1 PO walk than for 2 PO and 3 PO walks.

caption.p: Structural schematic of selected ASO molecules with 1 PO walk reflecting how the position of PO modification in a backbone towards 5‐methylcytidine (MeC), thymidine (T) and adenosine (A) nucleosides impacts the stability (based on data from Figure 3, top panel).

sec.title: Stability Study of ASOs in Mouse Liver Homogenate. Comparison of Metabolic Profiles in Biological Matrices
sec.p: After observing the intriguing stability increase associated with sequence‐dependent PS to PO swaps following incubations with mouse serum and PDEI, we aimed to explore whether these patterns could be observed in a more complex biological matrix, such as mouse liver homogenate.

Figure 5 provides a direct comparison of ASO stability in mouse serum and mouse liver homogenate for ASOs with 1 PO walk for both sequences. The inherent stability of the mixed PS/PO backbone patterns in both matrices shows a strong correlation, particularly for sequence 2 (Figure 5B). However, under these incubation conditions, ASOs were generally more stable in liver homogenate than in serum (Figure S6).

caption.p: Correlation of metabolic stability for 5 μM ASOs with 1 PO link in the backbone and explored for sequence 1 (A) and sequence 2 (B) incubated for 20 h in mouse serum and mouse liver homogenate. There is a strong correlation of stability for ASOs with both sequences in mouse serum and mouse liver homogenate (p < 0.0001 for A and B).

sec.p: In addition to the stability studies, we conducted metabolite identification analysis using HRMS. Several compounds showing increased stability (summarized in Figure 4) and sequence 2 (5–1–9) showing decreased stability were selected for analysis. Similar metabolite profiles were obtained using software data processing, Mass‐MetaSite or BioPharma Finder. Further structure identification was confirmed by BioPharma Finder Oligonucleotide sequence analysis based on MS/MS fragment analysis (Figure S7). Table 2 represents the metabolic profile for sequence 2 (10–1–4), and metabolic identification of other ASOs is summarized in Table S2. Our analysis revealed that mouse serum, mouse liver homogenate, and PDEI showed a similar hydrolytic pattern, with endonuclease cleavage predominantly at the PO linkage, followed by 3′‐exonuclease degradation towards the 5′ end, and the direct deletion of one nucleotide from the 3′ end (3′ N‐1) of the full‐length ASO.

caption.p: An example of metabolite profiling for compound Sequence 2 (10–1–4) incubated in mouse serum, mouse liver homogenate and PDEI for 20 h at 37°C.

fn.p: Note: PO links are labeled as “o,” when not specified are PS modifications; lightface type, DNA; underline type, locked nucleic acid (LNA); MeC, 5‐methylcytidine. Relative abundances of parent or metabolite were calculated as a ratio of MS peak areas of each analyte to the total area of identified metabolite and parent. The differences in MS responses and SPE recoveries of parent and metabolites were not taken into account for quantification.

sec.p: In order to develop an in vitro screening assay capable of capturing the nucleolytic potency of biological matrices, we screened various known nucleases alongside PDEI to assess their suitability. The properties of selected nucleases are described in Table S3. A 12‐mer at a concentration of 4.8 μM (0.6 nmol) was incubated with six different nucleases for 20 h at 37°C (Figure S8). Four nucleases, exonuclease T (ExoT), exonuclease VII (ExoVII), nuclease P1 (NucP1), and T5 exonuclease (T5Exo) completely degraded the 12‐mer. We then tested the stability of MALAT1‐Full PO (Figure S9) and MALAT1‐Full PS (Figure 6) after incubation for 20 h at 37°C with the selected nucleases. Under these incubation conditions, only ExoVII and NucP1 completely degraded MALAT1‐Full PO (0.6 nmol), while MALAT1‐Full PS (0.6 nmol) was degraded by the endonuclease NucP1. Interestingly, although ExoVII, a bidirectional nuclease, should not be inhibited by presence of a full PS backbone, we did not observe hydrolysis of MALAT1‐Full PS after incubation with 10 U of this enzyme (Figure 6).

caption.p: Titration of MALAT1‐Full PS (4.8 μM) with selected nucleases. The enzymatic activity of nucleases was 10 U, except for Nuclease P1, which was 5 U. Incubation was done for 0 and 20 h. (A) a summary of gel images, (B) band analysis showing the remaining percentage of MALAT1‐Full PS after incubation with selected enzymes. Data represent the mean from n = 1 replicates, 2 data points.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This work represents a comprehensive series of in vitro ASO stability assessments in different matrices, purified snake venom PDEI, mouse serum, and mouse liver homogenate. The examination of 83 ASOs with two sequences and various PO/PS content revealed structure‐dependent stability patterns. The data obtained from the nucleolytic sensitivity observed with 3′–exonuclease PDEI and mouse serum demonstrate a dependence on both PO content and sequence composition. It is evident that (i) a lower PO content in the PS‐modified oligonucleotide backbone provides higher stability, in keeping with established knowledge; and (ii) novel structural insights show how the backbone's base sequence has a larger impact on stability with increased PS content. With regards to (i), it has consistently been shown how the stability of mixed PS/PO ASOs considerably drops when exchanging three or more PS links with PO modifications [20, 28]. However, this effect was possible to mitigate by introducing 2′‐sugar modifications such as BNAs [20, 25].

In contrast to previous reports suggesting that LNA‐bases in the wings of PO‐oligonucleotide gapmers provide protection against nuclease‐hydrolysis [29], this study observed that gapmer PO MALAT1‐LNA ASOs are degradable with 3′‐exonucleases, both PDEI and mouse serum.

A notable pattern is that purine‐base‐rich oligonucleotides are generally more stable than pyrimidine‐base‐rich oligonucleotides [30]. By closer inspection of the composition of the last four nucleotides from the 3′ end, sequence 1 contains 50% purines, while sequence 2 only carries purine nucleobases in this region (Figure S10). It is observed that the ASOs from sequence 2 with the PO walk in the LNA flanking region at the 3′ end are more stable compared to sequence 1 (Figure 3 and Figure S4), consistent with previously published data [30]. However, the mere relationship that sequence 2 with overall 50% purine content would be more stable than sequence 1 with 37.5% purine bases is not evident in this study, except when focusing on the LNA wings. The pyrimidine‐base richer sequence 1 is even more stable than sequence 2 when exposed to mouse serum or mouse liver homogenate. However, it can be reasoned that the difference of six or eight purine bases in a 16‐mer may be too small to yield a significant impact, and a more detailed understanding of the impact of base sequence on stability would aid rational ASO drug design.

Another systematically investigated chemical modification is cytosine methylation. Specifically, 5‐methylcytosine (MeC) is a common c modification found in vertebrate and plant DNA, constituting 1%–5% of the total DNA. This modification can enhance RNA–DNA heteroduplex stability, mitigate the negative impact of full PS‐ASOs on intrinsic immune response, regulate metabolism, and conciliate stress‐induced cellular survival. In eukaryotes, gene expression activation is directly linked to cytosine methylation, while in prokaryotes, MeC plays a role in controlling gene expression as well as in the diminution of endonucleases [31, 32, 33, 34, 35].

In this study, we observed the impact of a MeC on the stability of ASOs, particularly for the 1 PO walk. We found that exchanging PS to PO link after MeC from the 3′ end increases resistance toward nuclease hydrolysis, while the same exchange before MeC has no protective effect. This suggests that nuclease access to PO links for hydrolysis is hampered by the neighboring MeC, possibly due to the orientation of the methyl group introducing a steric block. Additionally, we observed another sequence‐dependent phenomenon: increased stability of ASOs when PS was exchanged for PO between thymidine and adenosine nucleosides in the direction 5′ T–A 3′. However, when the PS to PO exchange is located between 5′ A–T 3′ or 5′ T–T 3′, no protective effect is observed.

One goal of this study was to explore the potential replacement of biological matrices such as mouse serum with alternative enzymatic systems possessing 3′ exonuclease activity (Table S3). The use of nucleases, either in isolation or as a mixture, would reduce the need for animal‐origin biological matrices in line with the principles of the 3Rs. Our findings demonstrated that PDEI shows similar hydrolysis potency as mouse serum towards ASOs with sequence 2 and 1 PO walk (Figure 3B, top graph), contrary to expectations due to the perception of PDEI as a pure 3′ exonuclease. Previous reports suggested that exonuclease activity was completely blocked by five consecutive PS modifications [36]; however, our study found that PDEI degrades ASOs even with nine PS modifications from the 3′ end, and good stability required 11 consecutive PS modifications (Figure S4). This observation aligns with the additional endonucleolytic capability of PDEI also reported by others [37]. While Eder and his group reported that ASOs are specifically degraded by 3′ exonucleases in serum [27], another group has shown that the endonuclease DNase1 is a major mouse serum nuclease that cleaves single‐stranded DNA [38]. Our direct comparison of nuclease‐mediated hydrolysis in PDEI and mouse serum shows highly similar stability patterns in all PO walks, supporting the fact that both, PDEI and mouse serum exhibit endonuclease activity (Table 2 and Table S2).

Building on the stability investigation for ASOs with both sequences and the 1 PO walk, we utilized a more complex nucleolytic matrix, mouse liver homogenate, and compared the data to that obtained with mouse serum. The biological matrices showed a strong correlation in stability, especially for sequence 2, with sequence 1 generally exhibiting higher stability in both matrices compared to sequence 2. ASOs displayed a trend of generally being more stable in mouse liver homogenate (Figure S6). This could be attributable to ASOs binding to liver proteins, reducing the free fraction available to nucleases. Alternatively, the proportion of nucleases in the total protein content of the homogenate may be smaller than in serum or in isolated enzyme PDEI. Comparing the biotransformation data from the three in vitro systems revealed similar metabolic profiles, with endonuclease activity occurring first, followed by 3′–exonuclease degradation (Table 2 and Table S2). Previous work by Li et al. [39] has shown that in vivo metabolite profiles of a GalNAc3‐conjugated full PS gapmer ASO in different animal species and human display a similar pattern, aligning with our in vitro findings.

As the mouse matrices as well as the PDEI incubations could replicate the in vivo observations [39] that ASO gapmer degradation begins with endonuclease‐mediated cleavage, followed by 5′‐and 3′‐exonuclease‐mediated hydrolysis, there is the opportunity that simple enzyme systems can be applied to generate in vivo metabolites. To explore the concept, the most stable reference compound in the dataset, the MALAT1‐Full PS ASO, was exposed to other nucleases. With the high‐activity endonuclease NucP1, a complete hydrolysis of the MALAT1‐Full PS was achieved in vitro. Additionally, nuclease screening identified the potential of a bidirectional exonuclease, exonuclease VII, to hydrolyse MALAT1‐Full PO. These findings can form the foundation for an in vitro nuclease capable of replicating additional nucleolytic activities and metabolite patterns observed in vivo. The availability of such an in vitro method to predict metabolic liabilities is fully aligned with the emerging regulatory expectations that in vitro methods shall be considered in the nonclinical safety assessment of oligonucleotides [40]. In a drug discovery setting, in vitro studies can guide the selection of the most stable ASO molecules prior to in vivo testing and replace animal serum and tissue homogenate incubations in compliance with the 3R perspective.

In conclusion, the assessment of ASO stability prior to in vivo ADME studies is an essential part of the design–make–test–analyze cycle. We have established a robust in vitro assay to determine the stability of newly synthesized ASOs with varying PS/PO content and sequence compositions.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
